channel.title: Programming languages
channel.description: In your opinion... What is the best/easiest language to use/implement. Or what is your favorite. The point of this topic is to find out what language I should start learning/ continue learning.

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

Java is one of the most widely deployed and has a vast amount of core and external libraries at your feet; if you require more speed you can invest in a less abstract language such as C++, for game logic (and when development time is a priority) you might want to look into scripting languages such as Python.

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:70, topic:451834”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=554722.msg4070129#msg4070129 date=1344272585]

Haha, no.
C# feature wise is far superior, the platform however, is a bit meh because it isnt completely multi platform, although Mono is getting close to fully supporting most of the important features.

They both pull a portion of their syntax from C++/C, have garbage collection, have similar keywords, have similar type systems, are compiled to machine code at runtime, etc.

C# does seem to be winning out on the number of features, but then again I wasn’t arguing for superiority of one language over the other (nor would I use number of features to argue such a thing).

Of course you wouldn’t decide which one is superior based on the number of features. However, if C# has multiple good language features that java lacks - then clearly C# is superior. Here’s a comparison, doesn’t cover C# 5.0 though. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_C_Sharp_and_Java#Feature_comparison

And finally I have to say the obvious. C++ is the most superior language. Those who are interested should also read what the new C++11 standard adds. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%2B%2B11
[/quote]

cde.jpg550×544

relevant[/quote]
not at all?

Read full topic

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Omer, post:12, topic:451886”]@Xellium
Perl is such a obscure programming language. Perl programmers take pride in writing obscure programs. I don’t think it’s best for a beginner.
e.g @H=@h=(176,138,140,17,87,54,126,182,217,223,136,130,136,117,73,52,154, 134,161,36,33,92,60,51);for(;$j<24;$j++){$x=0;for($k=0;$k<24;$k++){$x +=@h[$k]<<($j*$k%24);$x%=241;}@H[$j]=$x;}print pack('c*',@H)
Is valid Perl code.[/quote]
Gotta love Perl and it’s obscureness

Read full topic

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

What is the…

Best?
That question is too subjective for me to even attempt an answer.

Easiest to use?
Python.

Easiest to implement?
Assuming you mean ‘easiest to write code in’ and not ‘easiest to write a compiler/interpreter for’, that completely depends on the problem you’re trying to solve. Some languages are better suited to particular problems than others.

Favorite?
Ruby.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Omer, post:14, topic:451886”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=554722.msg4067305#msg4067305 date=1344015546]

@Xellium
Perl is such a obscure programming language. Perl programmers take pride in writing obscure programs. I don’t think it’s best for a beginner.
e.g @H=@h=(176,138,140,17,87,54,126,182,217,223,136,130,136,117,73,52,154, 134,161,36,33,92,60,51);for(;$j<24;$j++){$x=0;for($k=0;$k<24;$k++){$x +=@h[$k]<<($j*$k%24);$x%=241;}@H[$j]=$x;}print pack('c*',@H)
Is valid Perl code.
[/quote]That’s because it’s horribly formatted. If you look at it it’s rather simple…

I don’t even know Perl and I can tell that it’s just an encoded set of characters that represent a message, then it merely decodes it and prints the message.

Anyway, you can break conventions and get horribly looking code in pretty much any language… Here is the Scala equivalent while using the same algorithm (use the interpreter):

val h=Array(176,138,140,17,87,54,126,182,217,223,136,130,136,117,73,52,154,134,161,36,33,92,60,51);val H=h.clone for(j<-0 to 23){var x=0;for(k<-0 to 23)x=(x+(h(k)<<j*k%24))%241;H(j)=x};print(H.map(_.toChar)mkString)
What is weird to me is that the Scala version is only 14 characters longer (while still being a statically typed language), but seems much more readable (to me at least, but that’s probably because I’m used to Scala’s syntax).

That’s good for you. Would you like a medal?[/quote]You’ve completely missed the point… Then again, I went on a tangent.

You took a very straightforward JAPH and claimed that it was obscure. JAPH seems to be ingrained in the Perl culture, not something that is obscure. And the entire point of a JAPH is to use obscure/surprising elements of the language in order to obfuscate the program. So, using something that is intentionally meant to be obscure to argue the language is obscure is completely retarded.

Also, the idea to write obscure code isn’t language specific… There are things like the International Obfuscated C Code Contest, and in more general terms, golfing. See: http://codegolf.stackexchange.com/

Anyway, you’re taking code that is intentionally made be obscure and pretending like it’s representative of the language as a whole, it’s not. Also, if you take a look at legitimate Perl applications, you’ll see that it’s not that bad.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:51, topic:451834”](sorry if this is seemingly degrading to Ruby, I’m not familiar with it nor is it commonly used, so I assume it is limited).[/quote]Ruby is good, i like the language.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:46, topic:451834”][quote author=pro banana link=topic=554722.msg4065335#msg4065335 date=1343835822]

Easy and best don’t come together. There are so many easy languages, but none of them are good. The worst kind of programmers are the hipsters. Even this forum has a few high profile hipsters - s1gma being the most notorious one. They learn a handful of these easy languages, at a mediocre level. Their principle is that the more hipster-languages you know the better. Most of these languages have no real world usage. But that doesn’t bother the hipsters - they like to sit on grass, have a picnic, discuss lisp, scala, python, java or whatever. However, the goal should be to master one or two superior languages. I recommend C++. It’s the most superior language, but also extremely difficult. Weigh your options carefully or you might get burnt. C# is also good.

lol at python/java having no real world usage and C++ being difficult…

I’ve heard that C++ can be frustrating especially with memory allocation. There’s also alot that you can do wrong without even realising it.

Inb4flame for me not knowing anything about C++ these are just things that people told me.
[/quote]
c++ is only frustrating due to the redundancy of std and shit that is spewed out on compilation/runtime error. i’d say c is more difficult to become good at since OO doesn’t exist - imo C is basically a really high level assembly.[/quote]

You’re saying that C is more difficult because it doesn’t have classes? People write OO code in C. The perfect example of a C constructor/destructor pair are fopen and fclose. The C++ core language is huge, several times bigger than the C core language. There are so many language features (each of them has its use) and so many corner cases for each feature.

What’s redundant about the standard?

Read full topic

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Omer, post:12, topic:451886”]@Xellium
Perl is such a obscure programming language. Perl programmers take pride in writing obscure programs. I don’t think it’s best for a beginner.
e.g @H=@h=(176,138,140,17,87,54,126,182,217,223,136,130,136,117,73,52,154, 134,161,36,33,92,60,51);for(;$j<24;$j++){$x=0;for($k=0;$k<24;$k++){$x +=@h[$k]<<($j*$k%24);$x%=241;}@H[$j]=$x;}print pack('c*',@H)
Is valid Perl code.[/quote]That’s because it’s horribly formatted. If you look at it it’s rather simple…

I don’t even know Perl and I can tell that it’s just an encoded set of characters that represent a message, then it merely decodes it and prints the message.

Anyway, you can break conventions and get horribly looking code in pretty much any language… Here is the Scala equivalent while using the same algorithm (use the interpreter):

val h=Array(176,138,140,17,87,54,126,182,217,223,136,130,136,117,73,52,154,134,161,36,33,92,60,51);val H=h.clone for(j<-0 to 23){var x=0;for(k<-0 to 23)x=(x+(h(k)<<j*k%24))%241;H(j)=x};print(H.map(_.toChar)mkString)
What is weird to me is that the Scala version is only 14 characters longer (while still being a statically typed language), but seems much more readable (to me at least, but that’s probably because I’m used to Scala’s syntax).

Read full topic

item.title: Programming languages
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:46, topic:451834”][quote author=pro banana link=topic=554722.msg4065335#msg4065335 date=1343835822]

Easy and best don’t come together. There are so many easy languages, but none of them are good. The worst kind of programmers are the hipsters. Even this forum has a few high profile hipsters - s1gma being the most notorious one. They learn a handful of these easy languages, at a mediocre level. Their principle is that the more hipster-languages you know the better. Most of these languages have no real world usage. But that doesn’t bother the hipsters - they like to sit on grass, have a picnic, discuss lisp, scala, python, java or whatever. However, the goal should be to master one or two superior languages. I recommend C++. It’s the most superior language, but also extremely difficult. Weigh your options carefully or you might get burnt. C# is also good.

lol at python/java having no real world usage and C++ being difficult…

I’ve heard that C++ can be frustrating especially with memory allocation. There’s also alot that you can do wrong without even realising it.

Inb4flame for me not knowing anything about C++ these are just things that people told me.
[/quote]
c++ is only frustrating due to the redundancy of std and shit that is spewed out on compilation/runtime error. i’d say c is more difficult to become good at since OO doesn’t exist - imo C is basically a really high level assembly.[/quote]

you do not need language enforced feature sets to write object oriented code. it’s done all of the time in C. look at the file system sub system in Linux, it serves as a great example.

to answer the topics question, my personal favorite is C. i love the control I have.

Read full topic
